Each month in our ‘Spotlight On…’ series, we explore a new city and its wine culture, diving into the drinking trends, where to go for great wines, and any unique products or services linked to the region. Keeping our finger on the pulse when it comes to the wider world of wine is critical when helping us to identify areas of opportunity for our clients, aiding our eventing arm ‘Wrapped’, and for our online product offering on Uncorked. Whether curious about the habits and happenings of a city, or looking for wine-centric areas to visit in the area, our ‘Spotlight On…’ series is for you.

As the warmer days approach, we turn our minds to one of Europe’s most visited holiday destinations, Florence, known not only for its abundance of Renaissance architecture, amazing food, and host of museums, but being the heart of Tuscany, it comes of course with plenty of truly amazing wines. Quite a few of us in the CB office have now visited Florence in order to experience its world-class wine culture, and, having loved it, we thought we would share some of our insights.

OVERALL TRENDS

  • Respect and pride for local Tuscan wines, which most offerings will consist of.
  • A unique culture of ‘Wine Windows’ scattered across the city.
  • Plenty of natural, organic, or otherwise sustainable micro-producers.
  • Celebrating the marriage between Tuscany’s wines and the locally produced food.

WINE WINDOWS

WINE WINDOWS OF FLORENCE

Perhaps the most famous thing about Florence’s wine scene is the prevalence of the idiosyncratic and much-photographed Buchettas, small windows designed in the 16th century for the newly deregulated sale of goods, specifically so that the servants of Florentine’s elite could sell off their Master’s wines in an easy manner, without needing to permit entry to the estate. Due to wine being one of the more common usages, they have become known by foreigners as ‘wine windows’, despite being used to sell a variety of goods such as gelato, bread, and other Italian delicacies. Even after falling out of use, and many being bricked up over the course of the next centuries, a few are still used today, and constitute a very memorable part of Florence’s 3000 year old wine story.

BAR HOPPING

Babae Florence

Location: Via Santo Spirito, 21R, 50125

Vibe: Cozy, intimate, elegant.

Known for: Probably Florence’s most famous ‘wine-window’, great selection of food & wine.

Enoteca Pitti Gola e Cantina

Location: Piazza de' Pitti, 16, 50125

Vibe: Elegant, modest, welcoming.

Known for: Using ingredients and dishes from Tuscan regions, pairing them with wines from the same area.

Vineria Sonora

Location: Via degli Alfani, 39R, 50121

Vibe: Quaint, passionate, rustic, trendy.

Known for: Wide range of lesser-known producers, as well as many natural & organic wines.

First Glass

Location: Lungarno degli Acciaiuoli, 6R, 50125

Vibe: Modern, oenophilic, educational.

Known for: Serving sample-bottles so you can try and learn about as many interesting wines as you want.

WINE AS ART

PRODUCER BIBI GRAETZ

As a city full of rich architecture and extensive museums, wine contributes a large part to Florence’s artistic tapestry. Last year, our Head of Operations, Sophie Burleigh travelled to Florence to visit one of our favourite innovative wineries, Bibi Graetz, and you can read the specifics of her trip here. Bibi Graetz is first and foremost an artist; as the son of Swiss-Israeli sculptor Gidon Graetz, Bibi quickly gravitated towards the visual art mediums, thereafter becoming a painter himself, whose work can now be found adorning not only his bottles, but the many walls across his winery as well. When you experience Bibi’s wine’s, it is clear that this artistry, this passion for colour, tone, hue, texture, remains with him up to this day, and has simply found another suitable channel in the world of wine-making; with the grapes as his canvas, and his assiduously developed techniques as his brush, he continues to be just as evocative, passionate, and visionary in his wine as he was in his painting. Inside the brightly-labelled bottles, you will find wines as lush and impressionistic as the art which surrounds them.

One anecdote which I think captures Bibi’s passion and extravagance, surrounds a wine he released in 2020 entitled ‘Soffocone’¸which, once you have acquired the translation, you will understand why there was a bit of a furore — one perhaps not helped by its label design: a tranquil storm of opulent curvature, swirled into the figure of woman, no doubt in preparation for the act the wine’s title refers to.

Only a 20-minute drive from Florence, Bibi Graetz is just one of the many amazing producers in the area willing and ready to accept visitors, and share their love for all things oenological. If you are interested in visiting Bibi Graetz, or any other wineries during your travels across, get in touch and we will be more than happy to arrange an unforgettable journey for you.
